# Conclusion

The three-point revolution has fundamentally reshaped the NBA, evolving it from a midrange-heavy game into a high-efficiency system defined by "Pace and Space." Our analysis confirms that this shift was driven not just by an increase in volume, but by a concurrent rise in skill; elite shooters maintained efficiency despite higher usage, and the "skill dividend" expanded to frontcourt players, effectively eliminating the traditional non-shooting center. This evolution has optimized scoring output, as teams mathematically prioritized three-pointers and rim attempts over inefficient long twos. Future research could expand on this foundation by analyzing the specific defensive schemes evolved to counter this spacing or by isolating individual player archetypes to see which specific roles have gained or lost the most value in this new era.
